Introduction

Pediatric bony architecture differs from that of adults due to the presence of a more porous (ie, more flexible) cortex, a stronger periosteum (ie, less likely to be displaced), and cartilaginous growth plates.  These features predispose children to unique fracture types, including incomplete fractures (eg, buckle, greenstick) and growth plate fractures.  Other fracture patterns unique to children include nonaccidental trauma (NAT)-related fractures (eg, metaphyseal corner fracture, rib fracture), which must be differentiated from accidental injury.

Buckle (torus) fracture

Pathogenesis



Buckle fractures occur due to a sudden, longitudinal force applied to a bone.  Young children (age <10) have porous bone, which allows for compression of the distal metaphyseal cortex with an axial load.  This most frequently occurs with a fall onto an outstretched hand and involves the distal radius and/or ulna.  The cortices bend (buckle) without breaking or becoming displaced.  Therefore, a buckle fracture is considered a stable and incomplete fracture.

Clinical presentation



Buckle fractures present with pain and tenderness without gross deformity over the fracture site, which usually involves the distal forearm after a fall onto an outstretched hand.  Swelling and decreased range of motion are usually absent.

Diagnosis



X-ray classically shows bulging of the bony cortex (typically radius and/or ulna) without a fracture line (

image 1
).  More subtle fractures may show only disruption of the metaphyseal contour.

Management and prognosis



Treatment involves pain control and prevention of reinjury (eg, splint placement).  Because these are stable fractures, most buckle fractures heal within a few weeks without complication.

Greenstick fracture

Pathogenesis



Greenstick fractures most commonly occur with a fall onto an outstretched hand but can also occur due to direct trauma.  The fracture involves only one side of the bony cortex (ie, incomplete fracture) rather than extending through the width of the bone because the periosteum surrounding the bone is thick and strong in children.  The opposite side typically has a deformation or bend without a break in the periosteum or cortex.

Clinical presentation



Greenstick fractures present with pain, tenderness, and swelling over the fracture site, which usually involves the forearm after a fall onto an outstretched hand.  Ecchymoses, decreased range of motion, and mild gross deformity may be present.

Diagnosis



X-ray shows a fracture line with interruption of the bony cortex and periosteum of one side of the bone.  The opposite side is intact, although it may appear bowed, curved, or buckled due to compressive forces (

image 2
).  The paired bone (eg, ulna in a patient with a radial fracture) often has a plastic deformation (shaft bowing/curvature).

Management and prognosis



Prompt reduction (if displaced) and immobilization of the forearm is required for greenstick fractures because they are considered unstable due to the potential for refracture or further displacement if improperly treated.  Repeat x-rays should be performed prior to cast removal to confirm bony union.  Once the fracture is fully healed, no long-term complications are expected.

Plastic deformation

Pathogenesis



Plastic deformation is characterized by bending or bowing of a long bone (usually ulna or radius) due to a longitudinal force (eg, fall onto an outstretched hand).  Although there is no fracture line, plastic deformation is considered an incomplete fracture due to microdisruptions in the bony cortex at the site of angulation.  The more porous structure of bone in children as compared to adults allows for increased flexibility and increases the risk for plastic deformation.



This type of incomplete fracture can present in isolation but often develops in a paired bone with the other bone sustaining a different type of fracture (eg, plastic deformation of the ulna with a greenstick fracture of the radius).

Clinical presentation



Patients typically have pain at the site of angulation after a longitudinal force has been applied, such as forearm pain after a fall onto an outstretched hand.  There may be visible curvature to the forearm depending on the degree of angulation.

Diagnosis



X-ray of a plastic deformation shows bowing of the involved bone without a fracture line.  The paired bone may also show plastic deformation or have a complete or incomplete fracture.

Management and prognosis



Plastic deformation often self-corrects or normalizes with immobilization alone.  However, deformations with significant angulation (eg, >20 degrees) may require reduction.



Uncorrected plastic deformations may result in limited range of motion (eg, pronation, supination), particularly because mechanical alignment of paired bones (eg, ulna and radius) is required for full functionality.

Physeal (growth plate) fracture

Pathogenesis



The growth plate, or physis, is composed primarily of cartilaginous tissue and is responsible for longitudinal growth of bone.  The region of the physis immediately adjacent to the epiphysis consists of hypertrophic chondrocytes and a thin layer of newly forming calcified bone.  This portion of the growth plate is particularly susceptible to trauma and fracture in growing children.  Mechanisms of growth plate fractures include direct trauma, twisting/rotational forces, and repetitive pressure/impact.

Classification



Physeal fractures are categorized anatomically by the Salter-Harris classification (

figure 1
):



  • Type I:  growth plate only
  • Type II:  growth plate and metaphysis
  • Type III:  growth plate and epiphysis
  • Type IV:  growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
  • Type V:  compression fracture across growth plate


Type I is generally considered the least severe and type V is the most severe.  The most common subtype is Salter-Harris type II, and type V is rare.

Clinical presentation



Growth plate fractures present with focal pain, swelling, and tenderness at the fracture site, which involves the distal end of a bone (eg, radius, tibia, femur).  Deformity and limited range of motion may be present, and refusal to bear weight may occur with lower extremity fractures.

Diagnosis



X-ray of growth plate fractures for types I-IV shows a fracture line through the physis (

image 3
).  The epiphysis or metaphysis may be involved depending on the subtype.  Type V fractures are often difficult to diagnose with x-ray alone.



CT or MRI may be indicated for suspected growth plate injuries with subtle abnormalities on x-ray (eg, growth plate widening suggestive of physeal injury).

Management



Treatment of growth plate fractures depends on the anatomic location of the fracture line:



  • Types I and II are extraarticular fractures that can typically be treated with closed reduction and casting.
  • Types III and IV are intraarticular fractures that usually require open reduction and internal fixation.
  • Type V fractures are generally treated with casting, and patients should be nonâ€“weight bearing.  These fractures are often diagnosed in retrospect in a patient with growth arrest of the involved bone because this subtype is challenging to diagnose with initial x-ray.

Prognosis



Prompt treatment reduces risk for long-term complications.  However, any injury to the growth plate, particularly with compression fractures (type V), can cause premature growth arrest and lead to persistent limb-length discrepancy.  This pathophysiology often involves formation of physeal bars, or bony bridges across the growth plate.

Fractures associated with non-accidental trauma (NAT)

Fracture patterns



Certain fracture types should raise concern for NAT, particularly in children age <3 (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).  These fracture patterns are generally difficult to develop accidentally based on a child's developmental abilities:



  • Metaphyseal corner fracture (
    image 4
    ):  These fractures are seen as metaphyseal fragmentation of a long bone on imaging and result from forcible pulling or twisting of an extremity.
  • Rib fractures:  Compression of the chest (squeezing) may result in rib fractures, often posterior, multiple, and bilateral. 
  • Long bone fractures:  Nonaccidental twisting of a long bone (eg, humerus, femur) can result in a fracture.  Although these injuries (eg, femoral spiral fracture) are highly suggestive of NAT in a nonambulatory child (eg, infant), they can occur accidentally in older children.  Notably, spiral fractures of the distal tibia can be seen in ambulatory children age â‰¤3 due to a self-induced twisting injury during a low-impact fall in the early walking years.  This type of fracture is known as a toddler's fracture and is not associated with NAT.
  • Skull fractures:  Multiple or depressed skull fractures should raise suspicion for NAT.  Linear skull fractures are less commonly due to NAT.

Clinical presentation



Features of patient history that may be suggestive of NAT include the following:



  • Delayed presentation for medical evaluation
  • Inconsistent history provided by caregivers
  • Implausible history (eg, developmentally inappropriate mechanism) provided by caregivers


Examination findings other than fractures that should raise concern for NAT include bruises that are patterned or in noninjury-prone areas (eg, trunk, ear), well demarcated burns, subconjunctival hemorrhages (beyond neonatal age), or oral/nasal injuries in nonambulatory children.

Evaluation



  • Skeletal survey:  A comprehensive set of x-rays to evaluate for multiple fractures at different stages of healing
  • Funduscopy:  A dilated examination to assess for retinal hemorrhages
  • CT scan of head:  Neuroimaging to evaluate for intracranial injury (eg, subdural hematoma)

Management



Management of suspected NAT is multidisciplinary and includes reporting to child protective services and involvement of social services and law enforcement.



Fractures should be managed based on specific pattern type (eg, splinting for nondisplaced metaphyseal corner fracture).

Summary 



Certain fracture patterns in children (

figure 2
) differ from adults due to the presence of a more porous cortex, stronger periosteum, and cartilaginous growth plates.  Incomplete fractures generally heal without complication and include buckle fractures (bony bulge) and greenstick fractures (interruption of periosteum and cortex on only one side).  Growth plate fractures result in a break through the physis with the potential of growth arrest.  Features associated with nonaccidental trauma (eg, metaphyseal corner fractures, long bone fracture in nonambulatory child) must be differentiated from accidental injury.
